step1.sentence: You can place an order online and pick it up in store the same day.

step2.story: The bakery required customers to place orders at least forty-eight hours in advance for custom cakes. The policy had reduced stress for the kitchen, improved quality, and, unexpectedly, made the cakes feel more special to customers who had planned ahead for them.

step3.story: The supply chain consultant had been called in after a production stoppage revealed that the company had been placing orders reactively rather than predictively. Suppliers were given unpredictable demand signals, which led to either overstocking or shortages depending on the week. The fix was less a technology solution than a discipline change: planning procurement cycles further in advance, sharing demand forecasts with key suppliers, and treating ordering as a coordination activity rather than a transaction. The stoppage had been expensive. The lesson it forced was worth more.
